title: Pennington Flash Country Park Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Keith Williamson / Pennington Flash
images.caption: Looking roughly northwest across Pennington Flash near Leigh. A flash is a type of lake created through mining subsidence.

images.title: Graham Horn / Pennington Flash
images.caption: Sunken land due to colliery subsidence has led to many lakes known locally as flashes. This is the largest, Pennington Flash, now an important nature reserve with many different species of birds to be seen. The canal runs along an embankment above the surrounding land, the banks having been raised at various times to cope with the sinking land around.

images.title: Ian Greig / Glaze Brook entering Pennington Flash
images.caption: Glaze Brook entering Pennington Flash

images.title: Sue Adair / Kidney Pond, Pennington Flash
images.caption: Adult swan on the Kidney Pond as seen from Horrocks Bird Hide. Mining subsidence caused the land to sink and by 1905 this flash had been formed, flooding two farms and railway lines (which can still be seen near to the hide).

images.title: Galatas / Horrocks Flash
images.caption: A view over Horrocks Flash to the surrounding hills. Horrocks Flash is just one of several flashes making up Wigan Flashes. The area extends from Westwood to Pennington Flash at Leigh.

description: This 490 acre park is located in Leigh, Greater Manchester. The main feature is the 170 acre lake which is now a nature reserve with a number of bird hides. Over 200 bird species have been spotted at the park such as Black-faced Bunting, Nightingale, Marsh Harrier, Spoonbill and Leach's Storm-petre. The park has a number of well maintained paths suitable for cyclists or walkers. Facilities include an information centre, mobile cafe and nine hole golf course. The Bridgwater Canal also passes through the park so you can continue your walk/cycle along the towpath if you have time. You could try our Worsley Canal Walk which runs from Worsley in Salford Trail to the park. The Glazebrook Trail long distance footpath also passes the park. You could easily pick it up and head south through the countryside towards Glazebury, Great Woolden Moss and Glazebrook.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: There's no on site cafe but there is often a burger van and an ice cream van near the car park.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The park is a popular place for dog walkers so you will probably see other owners on a fine day.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: One nice idea is to pick up the Leeds and Liverpool Canal and follow it north west to Wigan Flashes Nature reserve where there are more birdwatching opportunities. You could also pick up the Wigan Canal Walk and further explore the area around the town. The canal towpath can be picked up just to the north of the lake. For more walking ideas in the area see the Greater Manchester Walks page.
